Belgia 1589 24 July To M
r
Secretary Walsingham
It may please yo
r
H. to be advertized,
t
as yet I have had
no aunswer from
e
generall States
astouching those Articles w
ch
I delivered unto them, for w
ch
they p
r
tend
t
they have not yet
hard from theyr Principalls, w
ch
I do not think will be long
but yet I see litell hope
t
ey will yeeld to any deputyes
t
shall come into
England
such an ample co
m
ission as ys required
at
is hand / in
e meane season the Enemy by all adv
r
tism
t
maketh great p
r
paration of his forces hetherward
, & unles
t
wee
be furder sucored
en there is apparance
t
we can be on
e suddaine
yt is gen
r
ally feared
t
he will passe
e Wael, wh
r
of
e
consequence doth put
em heer in some terro
r
For yf in
is
tyme of discontentment betwene hir
Ma
ty
&
em those contryes
should be overtaken w
th
any notable losse, happely
e common
people would deale somewhat roughly w
th
e principall causes
of those froward courses,
t
have bin held w
th
hir Ma
tye
The gen
r
all states & likewise
e
Counsell
have bin instant
w
th
me to intreat my
L. Burgh
for a Company of foote from
e
Brill
,
M
r
Borlas
for 2 companyes &
S
r
John Conway
for as many, for
t
we heare at this p
nt
t
the Enemy doth
not presse him. Because I do not doubt but yt is her Ma
ties
pleasure
t
in tymes of necessity
e su
fluous companies of
e
Cautionary Townes should be spared I have written very earnestly
to such effect as they required: My L. Burgh hath already
sent word
t
he cannot spare an Ensigne, but will fournishe
them by squadron of a convenient troupe & him self conduct
em
in
son. From
Flushing
&
Oostend
I have no aunswere as
yet. Moreover to
e self same effect, as
e Consell of
State hath written of late unto her Ma
ty
I have bin dealt w
th
all
publickly & very earnestly to sollicit
e sending back of those
companies or oth
r
s in theyr place w
ch
were drawen by
S
r
John
Norris
from hence & were to be returned
e fyrst of June
wh
r
to I have made
e same aunswere w
ch
they Rxd from y
r
H.
alleadging
e hindrance of
e
Portugall
s
vice through theyr
breach of Promyse to S
r
John Norris, also theyr continuall
infringing of
e Contrackt to
s
ve theyr p
nt
townes &
e small
regard w
ch
they have to content her Ma
tye
in any demand insomuch
as hir highnes doth grow very weary of theyr ungratefull
ceeding
. All this
ei labo
r
to excuse und
r
collor of beyng
mistaken, & oth
r
weak pretences, But howsoev
r
yt ys
e
consyder
ao
n of theyr owne weakenes uppon
e Ennemeyes app
r
ching
doth put
em at
is p
nt
in a great perplexity. Albeyt theye are
muche relieved w
th
this dayes newes. That
S
r
M
r
tyn Schenck
hath revictualle d
Berck
wh
r
upon
ey hope to
s
ve theyr tournes w
th
his forces. The Enterprise was don
e 18 of
is moneth wthout any
encounter of
e Ennemy for
t
S
r
Martyn Schenck conducted
his forces by secret wayes & so suddainely as he entred
e towne
fol.134v
[.] S
r
Fr
a
Wal
s
July 24
89
90
89
before
e ennemy could
ceave yt, w
ch
hath mervaylously spited
e Marquis
of Verambon & brought his troupes to a great disorder. This exploit
hath put S
r
Martin in a better conceat in those contreyes then any
of his actions heertofore. And likewyse
e English Captaynes & companies
do both give him a singular prayse for his conduct & Strategeme
as also for his carriage & co
r
tesye to them in
ticular, in w
ch
respect
yf yt might please yo
r
H. to thank him in her Ma
tyes
name & to
congratulate his happynes, yt would be a meanes to continew his devotion
toward
her High
nes
. In
e cause of
Vasseur
there ys nothing furder
don synce my laste to yo
r
H.
wh
r
wth I take my humble leave. July 23.
July 24
I ame earnestly sollicited by
S
r
Francis Vere
&
e oth
r
English Captaynes
w
th
S
r
Martyn Schenck to move this consell of State
t
they may
retourne to theyr garrison or be employed nerer home in
e quarter
about
Bommel
, & to
cure w
th
all
t
they maye Rx better payment
beyng very much distressed through theyr want of mony & death of all
thing
in those places where they ar in
s
vice. I do not doubt to o
[bteyn]
that they may be revoked to
s
ve yn these
ties, but for theyr paym
ent
I can but onely recommend theyr sute to yo
r
H. having sent unto you
for
e better testimony of theyr service & de
s
te S
r
M
r
tyn Schenck
letter written unto me. & yf by yo
r
H. procurem
t
they might receave
besydes theyr weekely lending
some extraordinary imprest upon theyr
payement, yt would be a spetiall incouragement both to them & to
others to de
s
ve
e like favor heerafter.
